title: Do teachers get attracted to students? - Quora

response.answer_text: They sure do! How can you not? They can be so very, very funny, kind, responsive, and everything. Sometimes they would play tricks on me. Should I get angry? I tried my best to be angry, but oftentimes the trick was so funny, I’d burst out laughing. Once when I teaching sentence structure and the logic of it, the brightest kid in the classroom brought in one of the thickest, fattest books I’d ever seen. He raised his hand and asked innocently, “Mrs. T, didn’t you say we could diagram in class any sentence we wanted on the checkboard?” I replied, “Yep, Jason, I sure did!” He turned around an winked at his classmates. “Okay, can we do this one?” He handed me a book. The book was a med book, There was underlined sentence. The sentence was over a page long. Truly it was! I told him, “Okay, would you like to do it for homework?” Pure silence fell in the classroom. There was another time when I returned to from lunch and found a beautifully wrapped box on my desk. I was just gorgeous. I opened the package and found a box of sand and dirt! The kids were looking at me expectantly. At first, I was going to yell and then just plain laughed. The list of things they did, their earnestness, their incredible kindness, their sense of logic, their sense of right and wrong hit me always. They were there to learn. But they always reach into my heart. Sometimes one or two would wait until everyone gone and then tell a sad story looking for help. Sometimes they just want to share something that had happened at home. How can you not develop feelings for them?

It depends on what you mean by attracted. Attracted in terms of, “ I want a relationship with that person”, no. They are students, meaning they are not peers, not friends, and especially not someone I want to date. They are students and I want them to learn what I have to teach them and to be successful in life. On the other hand, teachers are not blind. Someone is basically attractive or they are not, although beauty is in the eye of the beholder. Since I am heterosexual, I see the college age young women I teach and think, “I am sure she has lots of boyfriends.” I am the youngest of 6 in my family and I have many nieces. Can I acknowledge that my niece is attractive? Sure . Do I want to have a relationship with my niece? Hell, no. Having taught for almost 30 years I have always had a professional detachment from my students. Friendly but not friends. A professional detachment is equally applied whether the student is attractive or not.

I will say eagerness to learn and discipline. No matter what students is like, his/her learning attitude and good personal disposition is what i like the most in them as student. As per my belief, teaching and learning is not a profession with certain probation period but a process. Sometimes we teachers learn from students and most of the time we share what we have as academic content. I am teaching grade 11, 12 and bachelors students of computer science right now. I sometimes get chance to learn from my students. They teach the lesson of friendship and happiness occasionally. We teachers forget sometimes to smile and being teacher they become the reason for us to carry smile everyday where ever we go. Being good or even excellent in academics is not the only thing that makes our life meaningful. Let me share an experience why student's personal disposition is important. In one of the college that i’m engaged with, i use to teach a student whose academic result came to be excellent in every test that i take. He used to score not less than 90% in my subject i.e. computer science in every test and use to enjoy my class. But his personal disposition in class was like he treat himself as a super fellow in class. He used to hold attitude that was like very disturbing for other students in class. He was from a Rana family which is treated as high class in Nepal (I’m not trying to indicate all Ranas’ over here as scenario is somehow different in reality). FYI, Rana dynasty ruled the Kingdom of Nepal autocratically from 1846 A.D until 1951 A.D. and is treated as high class in general. He used to hold that kinda kingly attitude and turn his back to the college rules and regulations - misbehaving female students and even teachers. I don’t know why but he was a good students to me. College administration did talked with his parents and we all tried to keep him in track. But no any methods worked. Though being a talented student he was given Transfer Certificate from college. This is the first time i’m giving his example in public. I sometime regret for not being able to find the root of his attitude problem and help him. I feel so sad to know later-on that he was into some sort of addiction and that very reason took his life in an road accident in 2016. Every teachers like students who are eager to learn and disciplined as well. They need to upgrade themselves and be better version everyday. To be a student disciplined, he/she need to pose good attitude as well. Talented students may not always be good. What makes student a good student is eagerness toward learning and how they behave with teachers, parents and external stimuli that they face in everyday life. #geeksagar

Sometimes. I’m a university teacher, so my students are all adults. Still, I'm 50. I count myself very lucky that I don’t actually find people as young as my students attractive. I mean, many of them are lovely—I’m not blind. But if I think of the women in my life about whom I actually think “If I weren’t happily married, I’d ask her out,” they’re all at least 30 years old. I’ve taught junior-high, too, for two years, about 20 years ago. Now those students were children. Again, I could appreciate their cuteness, but no, not the slightest bit of attraction. Again, I am thankful that this is the case. I am sure some teachers are not so lucky. I also remember when I first started teaching, when I was barely older than the college students I was teaching. Yes, I was attracted to some of them. Age-wise, there would have been nothing very unusual about us dating. But I was their teacher. Romance and sex have no place in a teacher-student relationship. Even in my early 20s I knew that. Teachers who can’t figure this out shouldn’t be teachers.

Students tend to be good people. Teachers are attracted by the opportunity to help them learn and succeed. But if you mean attractive in a romantic/sexual way, no. If you mean, “I want you for my BFF,” no. If you mean, “I wish you were my kid,” no. They have attractions of that sort in their personal lives, away from their workplaces. I won’t say there are no exceptions, but even teachers who harbour such impulses know they’re unprofessional and are vigilant about keeping them under wraps. The even smaller minority who lapse are the ones you sometimes hear about in the news, and not in a good way. Most students are fortunate enough never to meet one of those. They’re few and far between, and the profession works to keep it that way.

Of course we develop feelings. We are human. Do you mean romantic feelings? If so, it is our professional duty to keep our feelings to ourselves. Do you mean contempt or some similsr feelings? Again, it would be unprofessional to show it. If we feel badly or even proud, THOSE feelings are appropriate to show in an appropriate way. If we are temporarily upset or disappointed, it is OK to show those feelings, too, as long as the student understands why you feel the way you do and it is temporary.

I’ve only taught youth in one-on-one settings and adults in groups. I just don’t think of attraction when I’m in teaching mode. It’s just not even on my radar. It’s so far from what I’m thinking about that it would never occur to me to think of any of my students in terms of attractiveness. My mind is focused on the content and on how the students are doing intellectually. Of course I also care about their personal lives as it relates to class, such as if a health issue makes it hard to concentrate or an additional disability makes it hard to retain new material, but other than that, I really am not thinking about anything personal.

Yes. All of them. For some its like being a leader, knowing they will go past anything I’ve done. With others, I am a train engineer. We are on that train, and he/she is standing on the track. We pull the break, but there is nothing in gods green earth that is going to stop what is going to happen to that poor kid. I see it is going to happen. I Yell, I pull the whistle, I scream, but there is only one end to that story, and it isn’t a happy one. I’m protective of them. I like most of them. I love a few of them. I don’t really care for a few also. No easy answer here as to WHAT I feel for them, but I certainly do feel something for every single one.

Clearly the other answerers have a different definition of “attracted to” from mine. Of course I was attracted to my students. I loved them; I even liked them. I spent fifty years in education. Why would I have stayed if I weren't attracted to the students with whom I worked?! Link (I hope.).Richard P. Morrall's answer to Why does one choose to become a teacher? I believe with all their knowledge they can do so much better. Well, it looks like a link. I hope it works.

I went into teaching because I am addicted to the buzz of students learning and having had a hand in that. It doesn't matter what students are like as they can all do that. It's perhaps more rewarding if I find it particularly hard to find the right way of engaging a student and then find something that works. Anything that impedes that process is a challenge especially when it is tied to political or bureaucratic agendas. Helping students learn is something I enjoy and I have respect for all students and in that sense - they are all amazing and I like all of them without exception.

Teachers for some reason are not considered to be human beings by some. Not sure why this is, but it is. “OMG, Mr. Mularz, you are wearing jeans!” Uh yes, and sometimes I eat pizza too!!! LOL So if you change your question to read, “Do plumbers find their customers attractive?” or perhaps “Do diners find their servers attractive” and you know the answers to those questions then you also know the answer to yours. Repeat after me…”Teachers are people”

Certainly, we're only human. Now, if you are fishing for ROMANTIC feelings, absolutely inappropriate. But there have been students in my career that are near and dear to me as if they were my own children. Some of my former students are my Facebooks friends with whom I still encourage, commiserate, give advice, congratulate and basically keep up with their lives. On the flip side, there are students I wish to forget ever were born and pray for their parents.

yes…some teachers are very attached to their students and they can go to any lengths to save their students from trouble…..I once had a teacher who was fired because the principal thought that she was supporting us and not her..

Some students you could predict that they will be handsome or pretty as they grow older (knowing parents can give an indication of this) but attraction is a different beast, entirely. People are attracted to personalities and students do not have a complete personality (IMO) as they have yet to discover who they are.

I have never had this problem but I have heard some comments from old students that some teachers had a tendency to cross lines and make remarks which were risky and offensive. When groups of teachers do this you may have to ask why this is allowed and then you understand why complaints never get taken seriously. Someone might be protecting them….. It is quite common and schools cover it up. The teachers are often serial offenders. In some cases it has been harmless admiration. Generally I think it is bad form to discuss students in this way and it will attract negative attention from colleagues. I ignore it, it is offensive and students need to be viewed respectfully. Leering gets noticed.

They can be proud of them. They can be happy with what the students have achieved. They can be disappointed the students haven’t achieved more. They can be impressed with the work the students have done. They can be satisfied that the students have achieved their potential, or not satisfied when they haven’t. They can be angry as all get out if the student does something crappy to another student. I am sure many teachers have had many feelings about many students throughout the centuries. Seems like kind of an odd question really, when you think about it.
I suspect that most teachers find a variety of other humans attractive. Some of them are probably students, and some of them are probably non-students.
Just about all of my students were beautiful one way or another. Otherwise I’m very much against acting as being attracted to any particular student.
I teach 6th grade. I recognize a beautiful child as exactly that. It isn’t sexualized at all, just a beautiful kid.
It’s super concerning this question is asked so frequently because it makes my stomach upset. I would sincerely hope not.
